title: rock-lives-doctor-alistair-macgowan-on-the-stones-of-edinburgh-and-the-stories-they-tell
story: And yes, there it is, fused into the stone, a tight spiral form that ascends like a staircase. An ammonoid. Some  million or  million years ago this was the shell for a marine mollusc of some sort that was feeding and breeding in the region of what is now the Anti-Atlas Mountains in Morocco.Related to squids, cuttlefish and octopuses, this creature died, sank to the bottom and was buried in the sediment. Eventually the shell and surrounding loose sediment grains were cemented together to produce solid rock.Millennia later it was quarried and transported halfway across the world to become part of the Scotsman Steps at the instigation of Turner Prize winning artist Martin Creed, for his  art installation Work No. .McGowan, all hair and enthusiasm, is speculating on how this little creature ended up encased in marble millennia ago. ldquoThere are very many dferent pathways to becoming a fossil, he explains.He traces the outline of the ammonoid with his finger. ldquoThe inner part has been preserved in a whiteish mineral, which Irsquom guessing is Calcite, and the outer part has been preserved in sediment because thatrsquos open like a bucket.As McGowan lies on the stone floor, people pass up and down the steps around us, oblivious.Obliviousness is the default human position, isnrsquot it  We accept the world as it is and rarely think about the how. Itrsquos typical human behaviour. ldquoMost people donrsquot think about how Maxwellrsquos equations relate to their mobile phone or how the internal combustion engine works, McGowan points out.And yet our st-century lives are rooted in the distant past. The stones beneath our feet, the stones in the buildings that surround us, are the physical evidence of the planetrsquos millennia-long story. Deep time made manest.On every street you walk on there are stones ndash sedimentary, igneous or metamorphic ndash that are in a way a form of frozen time travel. Stones from local quarries, stones from Caithness and Yorkshire and Morocco and Baia, stones laid down in the Carbonerous era and repurposed for our own use over the last few centuries. The world around us is a Tardis.Most of the time wersquore too busy popping into Starbucks for a Soy Chai Latte or checking our mobile phones to notice. But the past is all around us,wersquod only open our eyes. Today, the Doctorhas offered to lend me his.And there is so much to see in Edinburgh, this city built around and on top of an extinct volcano.More than that, the volcanic plugs of Arthurrsquos Seat, the volcanorsquos main vent, and the Castle Rock, have done much to shape the look and the settlement patterns of the city. Edinburgh is an example of geology as design.We are on a journey into the planetrsquos primordial past. It will take us from Morocco to Austria and from the Highlands to Argentina, all without leaving the old town. These are the stories of the stone of the city.ldquoThese slabs here are from Caithness, McGowan tells me, pointing at the paving stones beneath our feet as we walk down East Market Street towards The City of Edinburgh Councilrsquos offices.ldquoThey were the base of an ancient freshwater lake up around Orkney and down to round about the Moray Firth.The stone dates back some  million years ago to the Devonian era. At that time the environment in what is now the north of Scotland would have been arid.ldquoThe analogy we use for the Devonian is Death Valley in Calornia, McGowan explains. For anyone who has spent a winter in Wick that might be hard to imagine, but there it is.We move onto Waverley Court to look at the walls. Council workers come and go from the building. Some stand around outside having a fly cigarette, watching with vague interest as we start to feel up the sandstone faccedilade on the building.ldquoWersquoll just shuffle along a bit and yoursquoll start seeing some obvious fossils, says Doctor McGowan. ldquoThatrsquos an ammonoid, he says pointing to another ice cream cone on the side of the council offices. ldquoThe piece next to it is a two-dimensional section of a belemnite, he adds. ldquoBelemnites were around in the Jurassic and Cretaceous period, between  million and  million years ago.The sandstone the fossils are embedded in is smooth and creamy to the touch. As smooth and creamy as yoursquod want your le to be. ldquoTherersquos a lot of touching in geology, McGowan admits.He runs his hands over the walls of the building. ldquoThis is known in the trade as Baian gold limestone, he points out. ldquoThis is from the lagoonal environments in the Solnhofen in Eistadt, the lagoons where the archaeopteryx [a transitional fossil between dinosaurs and modern birds] comes from. No archaeopteryx here unfortunately, but very, very fossilerous.Fossilerous might be my new favourite word, I think, as he looks for more examples. We both caress the stone, tracing the shapes of ancient sponges and bivalves.We cross over the road and walk up the hill towards the Royal Mile. On the rise therersquos another building that has used Baian gold limestone as for its facia. The stone here is rougher textured, not so finished.Still, it has stories to tell. We stand back and take in the patterns that can be seen flowing across the surface of the stone. These stones were once the bed of a river, my guide explains. And, indeed, as I look, I can see the flow of the water, great sweeping arcs of it, a liquid path now scoured in stone.Over coffee in the City Art Centre Doctor McGowan charts his own course. It starts with feathers not rock.ldquoI was always interested in birds when I was wee. I was born in Paisley and I grew up in Aberdeen. Two of the big boys on my street were in the YOC, The Young Ornithologistrsquos Club, so I got into that.At university in Glasgow, McGowan says, he wanted to study astrophysics. ldquoBut my calculus remains a bit fy. Instead, he segued into geology. After uni, he worked for three years in a boatyard in Knoydart and spent time building mountain footpaths in Torridon and up Arthurrsquos Seat.He then went to Bristol to do a masters in paleobiology and then decamped to Chicago for his PHD, before eventually ing to Scotland. He is  now. His partner is an atmospheric physicist. They have three children, a -year-old girl and eight-year-old twins.In a bid to manage family commitments McGowan went freelance. And, so, he does upland bird surveys in the Highlands and Duke of Edinburgh expedition work.And when asked he will show people the geology of Scotland that surrounds them, whether that be up mountains or in the city itself.From birds to stones doesnrsquot seem an obvious step, I suggest. That turns out to be a very st-century notion. ldquoIf you go back to the th century, the heyday of the Victorian collecting mania, geology was very much part of natural history. Rocks, soils, fossils, minerals are the non-living part of natural history, what we call geoersity. If you like, they set the stage for the biological actors ndash the plants and animals ndash to strut upon.What he does is big picture stuff, you could say. ldquoThinking about evolution, but on enormous scales, up to the point where you are shting tectonic plates around and the signature that that will leave on the fossil records. And that feeds back to reconstructing what the environment was like.ldquoSo, itrsquos doing natural history, but on a really, really, big scale. And that does go onto the elements of what we are made up of, because we are all children of stars. Wersquore formed in supernovas.He brings out a map of the rocks and stones of Edinburgh, points out the volcanic crag and trail and the surrounding coal fields. His maternal grandfather used to be a miner before becoming the last provost of Prestonpans. His family story is written in the rocks that surround us.The city of Edinburgh is shaped by the geology of the landscape it is built upon. The layout owes much to the volcanic geology and the Norrsquo Loch which once extended from the Castle Rock down to Market Street.ldquoThe old town was incredibly tight and confined onto the crag and tail until pretty late on, McGowan points out. ldquoEdinburgh didnrsquot really break out of the old town because of a combination of the Norrsquo Loch, the fact that it was an important military site, and also dferences in the land ownership patterns.ldquoGlasgow is built on a series of ridges and valleys that are part of a drumlin field which are the result of the last ice age, whereas, here, you have one big feature that yoursquore working around. Itrsquos a mixture of geology setting the stage of what yoursquore going to do and then what people want to do. We set up our ecosystem as we want it.In Glasgow that meant building on the slopes of the drumlins. In Edinburgh the relatively soft sedimentary rock on the downhill side of the castle meant people could tunnel into it. ldquoYou could dramatically expand your living space. Itrsquos the th-century equivalent of people putting those sub-sub basements in in London.We walk on and eventually turn into St Johnrsquos Hill, climbing up past the NCP car park to a scrubby little garden full of plastic bottles, newspapers, empty Kronenberg beer cans and a small memorial to James Hutton, one of the founders of the science of geology who lived on this site until his death in .ldquoThis is how Hutton is memorialised in Edinburgh, McGowan points out. It is, it must be said, a slightly shabby little memorial garden for such an important scientic figure.But maybe the memorial is all around us. Its there up on Salisbury Crags where you can see what Hutton saw a dolerite sill caused by magma forcing its way between layers of existing sandstone rock. Millennia later this rock formation shaped Huttonrsquos thinking and was then named after him: Huttonrsquos Section.Edinburgh is a city that was made for the most part from local stone. On a map McGowan points out the ious quarries. Hailes, Craigmillar Hawkhill, Craigleith.But stone travels too. On Chambers Street, we stop at the statue of Greyfriars Bobby. McGowan rubs his fingers over the glossy, polished black grained stone at the base.ldquoI will make no comments on the tale, but this is Shap granite from Cumbria. Itrsquos very distinctive because of these very large phenocrysts, he says, pointing to the glittering crystals that pattern the black rock.Like everything, there are fashions in stone. Igneous rocks from Norway are popular for shop faces, for example.Glasgow, meanwhile, has more Portland stone than Edinburgh. But you can find one example on Hanover Street, now home to Lakeland and the Royal Society of EdinburghldquoThat was originally owned by one of the insurance companies, McGowan explains [the Edinburgh Le Assurance Company]. ldquoBy showing that you could bring that stone all the way from Portland you were basically saying, lsquoWersquove got the capital to pay out on your claim.rsquoAnd so, rocks, laid down millennia ago, are dug up and transported around the world. We shape the world that shapes us hellip those Caithness slabs in East Market Street can also be found around the Cutty Sark in London. Some, McGowan points out, have travelled as far as Buenos Aires.Wersquore only going as far as the Grassmarket, where we pop into Stan Wood Dinosaurs to meet its manager Matt Dale. He has had the fossil shop for the last  of its  years. This morning, he tells me, he has just sent his empty crates down to Bristol where they will be shipped out to America in time for a trade show he is attending in Arizona. Trade shows are where he picks up the bulk of his stock.Looking in one of the display cases McGowan points out ldquosnakestones from Whitby. ldquoThey used to be a tourist good luck charm, Dale explains. ldquoThe story is that when Saint Hilda arrived at her abbey, she was disgusted to find snakes there, so she turned them into stone and cast them into the sea.ldquoWhen people found ammonoids they didnrsquot know what they were and assumed they were the snakes.ldquoThere are lots of stories that are peoplersquos attempts to explain things in the natural world, adds McGowan. ldquoDragon myths, which are pervasive all over the world, are probably a mixture of people seeing ice age dinosaur bones because how  could you possibly explain this flying winged beast We tell ourselves stories about the stones that surround us. The stones tell their own stories.For a moment I think again about that little ammonoid fused in marble on the Scotsman Steps. Caught in stone, caught in time. A small mark on the face of eternity. The story of le itself.Doctor Al McGowan is an Edinburgh-based chartered geologist and qualied outdoor leader. He runs natural history-themed walking tours across Scotland. For more details, visit hillsofhame

title: vital-support-plans-for-pupils-disappearing
story: While not all children with additional support needsrequire a co-ordinated support planit has an important status because it is a legal document requiring councils to ensure pupils receive appropriate support.In particular, the documents are vital for pupils with more severe issue who require support from a number of dferent services such as education, social work or health.Before the Additional Support for Learning Act in , about two per cent of pupils in Scotland had a statutory support plan and, when the CSP was introduced, the Scottish Government promised there would be no decline in the proportion of children receiving them.However, since  there has been a year-on-year reduction in the number of CSPs opened, with the most recent figures showing a drop from , to just , last year.Worryingly, previous research has shown pupils from less advantaged backgrounds are more likely to be identied as having ASN, but are less likely to have a CSP because middle class parents are more likely to have the resources and resilience to pursue one even when councils are resistant.Professor Sheila Riddell, chair of inclusion at Edinburgh University, saidthe trend continued support plans could virtually disappear.She said: "Councils are largely unconcerned about the decline in the use of CSPs, regarding them as cumbersome and time consuming."Local authorities argue they prefer to use other types of plan despite the fact these are not specically education documents and have no directly enforceable rights associated with them."Parents, on the other hand, believe statutory plans are important to ensure childrenrsquos needs are properly assessed, recorded and reviewed."Mrs Riddell said there were "mixed messages" from the Scottish Government on the importance of CSPs.She added: "At a time when budgets are being squeezed, a number of changes are needed. The qualication criteria for a CSP should be simplied, so that a child should be entitled to a statutory support planthey require support not normally available in school."Secondly, there should be training for local authority and school staff so there is better understanding of the system in general, including statutory entitlements."

title: scale-of-female-genital-mutilation-treatment-for-city-health-boards-revealed
story: The statistics were revealed by Scottish Liberal Democrat MP Jo Swinson, who said the ldquobarbaric practice must be wiped out entirely.Responses to a freedom of information request from the party show that NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyderecorded treating women identied with FGM on at least  occasions in  and .In NHS Lothian, which covers Edinburgh,  occasions were noted over that two year period.Questions submitted to Scotlandrsquos  other territorial health boards showed that they had recorded very low or no cases of FGM in their area.In its response, NHSGGC stressed that it could not confirm the ldquotrue prevalence of FGM in the health board area because some patients may have been admitted to hospital for an unrelated issue.It is also possible that there are ldquosignicant numbers of patients with FGM who have not been admitted to hospital, the board said.The figures were revealed after the UNrsquos International Day of Zero Tolerance for FGM was marked on Wednesday.And at the start of February, the mother of a three-year-old girl became the first to be found guilty of FGM in the UK.The Ugandan woman, , from east London, was found guilty of cutting her daughter after a trial at the Old Bailey.East Dunbartonshire MP Ms Swinson, the deputy leader of the Liberal Democrats, said: ldquoThese figures show that NHS professionals across Scotland are recording treating women who have experienced FGM.ldquoIt is a barbaric and traumatic practice that must be completely eradicated. Nobody should be in any doubt that it is child abuse and it is against the law.ldquoThe Scottish and UK governments, police and other services must work closely to protect women and girls from FGM. They must also ensure that there are sufficient resources for training and support services to help women and girls who are victims of FGM to deal with the physical and psychological consequences.ldquoWe waited a long time to see the first conviction in the UK for female genital mutilation. It should pave the way for further concerted action.Dr Duncan McCormick, consultant in public health medicine at NHS Lothian, said: ldquoWe are very clear in our commitment to and responsibility for identying and treating children and women at high risk of FGM in Lothian.ldquoIt is a form of abuse and gender based violence that has serious short and long term physical and psychological consequences, andany health professional has concerns they have a responsibility to share that information to safeguard the wellbeing of women and children.ldquoFGM is a hugely complex and sensitive issue that requires health professionals to approach the subject carefully. We need to ask the right questions in a straightforward and sensitive way to establish the understanding and relationship needed to ensure that the girl or woman, and her family members, are given the care, protection and safeguarding they need.An NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde spokesman said: ldquoWe have no confirmation that FGM is being practised in Scotland, however there is intelligence that cutting does happen where in the UK.ldquoThere is a clinic at the Princess Royal Maternity Hospital, run by the SNIPS team , which sees all women who have disclosed FGM.ldquoFor the most part, they do not need any treatment and will more than likely go on to have a normal birth.ldquoA small number of women are referred to the gynaecological services. Of those who are referred, some request no treatment in the antenatal period, and would rather wait for the intrapartum period, which is the recommendation from The World Health Organisation.Minister for Older People and Equalities Christina McElvie MSP said: ldquoFGM is an abhorrent practice, a form of abuse and a violation of the human rights of women and girls.ldquoScotland already has robust laws in place to tackle this illegal practice and we are taking action to prevent and eradicate FGM and ensure that public and third sector services stand ready to support those at risk.ldquoWe want to strengthen protections further, introduce protection orders for women and girls at risk and place guidance for professionals on a statutory footing.

title: labour-plan-to-force-may-to-put-her-brexit-plan-to-decisive-vote
story: Shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer said Labour will use a Commons amendment to require the Prime Minister to hold another ldquomeaningful vote on her deal by February .The move is in response to fears that Mrs May is engaged in a ldquocynical attempt to run down the clock before the March  Brexit date in order to leave MPs with a stark choice of accepting her deal or crashing out of the European Union without any agreement.If no deal on the changes to the Brexit Withdrawal Agreement has been reached with Brussels by Wednesday, as seems overwhelmingly likely, Mrs May will address MPs on progress made, say more time is needed for negotiations, and table a ldquoneutral motion for debate the following day.Sir Keirrsquos new deadline is expected to be one of a range of amendments tabled for votes on Valentinersquos Day.The PM is promising another ldquomeaningful vote in the coming weeks but Labour will seek to take the decision out of her hands.ldquoWe have got to put a hard stop into this running down the clock, Sir Keir told the Sunday Times. ldquoAnd thatrsquos what we want to do this week.He believes the Prime Minister is ldquopretending to make progress but actually intends toto Parliament after the March   European Council summit the week before Brexit and offer MPs a ldquobinary choice ndash her deal or no deal.ldquoWe canrsquot allow that to happen, Sir Keir said. ldquoThere needs to be a day when Parliament says thatrsquos it, enough is enough.In the interview Sir Keir described Mrs Mayrsquos approach as ldquoreckless and ldquoblinkered and blamed her ldquotunnel vision for the devastating defeat suffered last month when MPs threw out her Brexit deal by a record  votes.ldquoItrsquos this blinkered approach thatrsquos got us to where we are, with her never wanting to see where the real majority is in Parliament, Sir Keir said.Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, who has written to the Prime Minister setting out his demands for a Brexit deal he could support, accused Mrs May of an ldquoutterly cynical approach.In a speech in Coventry he saidLabourrsquos plan ldquocould win the support of Parliament and bring the country together but Mrs May has so far ldquochosen the path of ision.ldquoIf she is unable to adopt a sensible deal because it would split the Tories, then the answer is quite simple: there must be a general election, Mr Corbyn said.The Prime Minister survived a confidence motion in her government tabled by Mr Corbyn, which could have led to an election, after her Brexit deal was overwhelmingly rejected by MPs in January.Mr Corbyn said that without an election ldquowe will keep all options on the table ndash as agreed in our conference motion ndash including the option of a public vote.In his letter to Mrs May, the Labour leader set out five demands, including apermanent customs union and close alignment with the single market.The move led to a backlash from pro-EU Labour MPs, but Sir Keir defended the approach and warned against a split in the party.ldquoWhen you go through something like Brexit, it is very important that you keep the opposition strong and united, he said.ldquoWe have to keep it together, because in the end, any chance of effective opposition goesan opposition party starts to lose members from their team.

title: labour-calls-for-sir-philip-green-to-lose-knighthood-if-allegations-are-true
story: On Friday details of the allegations made against Sir Philip were published by the Dailyafter his legal action against the newspaper ended at the High Court earlier that day.The report included claims he mocked a male employeersquos dreadlocks and groped a female executive, paying her more than pound million to stay quiet.And on Saturday Labour Party chairman Ian Lavery called for the retail tycoonrsquos honour to be removedthe reports are accurate.He said: ldquoIf the allegations are true, then Philip Green should be stripped of his knighthood.ldquoThe public rightly expect high standards from public figures and theyrsquore not getting it.ldquoThe honours system is clearly flawed and the Prime Minister should take steps to remove honours from people who bring their office into disrepute.ldquoNon-disclosure agreementsshould never be used to suppress allegations of criminal behaviour so the next Labour government will review the statute book to ensure that the law protects the voices of survivors.In October Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable also called for Sir Philip to lose his knighthoodthe allegations were true.Thesaid the Arcadia boss paid out millions in settlements with staff members, who include a senior female executive who was allegedly called a ldquonaughty girl by Sir Philip.The newspaper said he allegedly kissed her face on a number of occasions, slapped her bottom and made comments about her weight.According to the , Sir Philip also allegedly drew attention to the dreadlocks of a senior male executive in front of other staff, and referred to him ldquothrowing spears in the jungle.And the paper reported he was told not to come any closer by a woman whose face he is said to have grabbed, allegedly dragged another senior female staff member around in a headlock and allegedly smashed a male staff memberrsquos mobile phone in an aggressive dressing down.The court injunction was first sought after Sir Philip and an last week it emerged that he was dropping the case because it was ldquopointless after he was named in Parliament as the businessman behind an injunction against the newspaper.Lawyers representing the Topshop owner said the decision was prompted by Lord Hainrsquos identication of Sir Philip in the House of Lords in October last year, a day after theran a front-page story saying it was prevented because of the injunction.However, the judge declined to impose conditions to stop Sir Philip and the companies suing either theor the former employees in future, as requested by the newspaper.In his judgment, the judge said lawyers representing thehad said Sir Philiprsquos ldquounlawful conduct was ldquosufficiently serious to engage the public interest, including as it does unwanted contact of a title: rab-mcneil-we-dont-need-people-like-me-in-holyrood
story: For a start, it involves some travelling, which I deplore. I used to be made to travel, sometimes even abroad, in the line of duty, and wanted to go home by the time we were at departures in the airport.Even when I went to pleasant places for supposed pleasure, Irsquod be restive from the off, and breathe a sigh of relief as thejourneyended and familiar places ndash seashores, town halls, chip shops ndash came into view.I was discomfited, therefore, to read that many or even most middle-aged people are obsessed with travel and have a list of buckets into which theyrsquove placed countries they want to visit before making the final journey to Hell, which is what they deserve.Most of these headstrong hedonists already have foreign trips booked for this year, which suggests theyrsquove too much money and that the state should be taxing them more. I, meanwhile, deserve a bonus for staying at home and supporting the local economy.For  years, apart from short periods looking after chickensin East Lothian, and catsin Morningside, I havenrsquot stayed anywhere away from home, other than Skye several times a year.Most of my friends go abroad frequently and neverchanged or noticeably broader in the mind. Broader in the hips, yes. And,they were impressed with a better le where , the magic never lasts and they soon forget it as the pleasing tedium of le in Scotland reclaims their wayward souls.Mention of ldquoScotland reminds me that some bearded lout with halitosis of the personality alluded earlier to the controversial semi-countryrsquos First Minister.Shersquos had the audacity to set forth abroad, to yonder America, with the aim of representing Scotia Minor to the lieges there. However, as ever in a small-minded small country, somebody said this was a waste of taxpayersrsquo money, itself a fair description of the inidual under advisement: Jamie Greene MSP.Irsquom unfamiliar with this fish, though my researchers tell me that, last year, independence supporters dubbed him ldquothe thickest politician in Scotland. That seems harsh, particularly on Labourrsquos James Kelly who, for several years, held this crown unchallenged.Irsquove seen James perform and am surprised he isnrsquot still repeating primary school. Hersquos quite extraordinarily dense. Intrigued, therefore, by the Conservativesrsquo Mr Greene, I checked him out on Wikipedia where, right enough, his picture revealed a head that wouldnrsquot look out of place sticking out of the soil on an allotment.Just out of interest, or indeed otherwise, I looked up Mr Kelly too and found his nomenclature ldquodisambiguated from a pirate, crimper, saloon keeper, and member of Irish heavy metal band Altar of Plagues. Any of whom would probably make a better MSP.Now, not being bright myself, you might think Irsquod extend a hand of solidarity to such iniduals. But the dference between us is that I donrsquot stand for parliament. Itrsquos not just that Irsquom too dense. I could never tow a party line. Irsquove never made a speech. And, despite attending Holyrood twice a week for many years, never understood motions, amendments and standing orders.But even I,I so chose, could easily find myself elected as a list MSP, like Jamie and James, in effect the leftovers from elections. Theyrsquore elected indirectly from the list, which is a free pass to Holyrood for losers .For my taxpayerrsquos money, itrsquos time we re-evaluated this system, so that we get elected representatives who are well-travelled, oratorically confident, brave, bright and well turned out. Not people like me.CHIPS news, and the controversial comestibles could shrink by in after last yearrsquos wonky weather, according to top lardologists. The potato crop may have been grievously affected, leaving smaller, misshapen spuds, from which sculpting a decent-sized chip might become impossible.Asthat werenrsquot grim enough news, nutritionists are calling for fish and chips portions to be reduced in size by inflicting smaller cartons on consumers. How dastardly of them.Every Friday recently, I had a humungous fish supper served in a in-wide box, and herersquos what these food boffins donrsquot factor in: driving home with this monstrous supper safely strapped in to the passengerrsquos seat, the aroma would sometimes cause a tear of happiness to fall down my cheek, and I found myself experiencing the unusual feeling that le might be worth living after all.They say that being happy is good for our health and, in that sense, I estimate that each fish supper has added a month to my le. To reduce them in size would diminish our joy, making us sullen and unproductive, with deleterious consequences for the health service and economy.If this coming year is truly to feature little chips in little cartons, I fear for the country, and would advise the Samaritans to draft in extra troops.HOW amusing to read that Scottish islands are producing guides on how to use single-track roads for visitors.Visitors would be within their rights to reply: ldquoWhy donrsquot you join up all the passing places and make normal, two-lane roads, as they have in the rest of the world Irsquove never understood single-track roads. Before they were forced to create passing places, did the clots who built them not envisage the possibility of traffic coming the other way Presumably, as with everything in our increasingly wealthy society, expense will be the reason for leaving them so ridiculously user-unfriendly. In the poor past, people could build roads but, in the rich present, we canrsquot even widen them a little.Itrsquos the same with the South Edinburgh Suburban Railway. The Victorians built it from scratch: trains, track, stations and staff to run them. Now we canrsquot afford to reopen it, even with the infrastructure already in place.All we can afford these days are massive salaries for fat cats and footballers. Itrsquos called progress. You wouldnrsquot understand.

title: want-to-meet-scotlands-extreme-adventurers-join-our-conversations-with-cool
story: Thatrsquos why last year we chose television adventurer Aldo Kane to top our list of coolest Scots ndash because of the way he has pushed limits and performed feats most of us find unimaginable.Next month we launch a series of events ndash talks, debates, showcases ndash based around The Herald on Sundays Cool List and staged by the prestigious Edinburgh Grand hotel.Called Cool Conversations, they will bring together writers, musicians, mindfulness gurus, explorers of landscapes and ideas, bloggers and creative thinkers.First up, on March , in a rare moment of being back in Scotland, rather than cave-ing in Mexico or tackling Narcos, will be Kane himself. He headlines the debut event, Going To Extremes, and will be joined by others who have taken on the elements, performed daredevil stunts or tested themselves in the wilderness.Among them are Robbie Grfith, whose Trainspotting-inspired parkour tricks were so cool they went viral, Hazel Robertson, explorer-in-residence at Royal Scottish Geographical Society who has run a -mile ice Ultra in snowshoes and trekked across Alaska, and Calum Maclean, the wild swimmer who has brought new meaning to the word ldquoBaltic.Cool Conversations will be your chance to ask burning questions, hear tales from, and to share time and perhaps a cocktail with, some of Scotlandrsquos coolest. Tickets are available at pound each. To whet your appetite here are a few stories from these boundary-pushing adventurers.Aldo KaneExtreme adventurer, Moment of cool: Beating Ed Stafford in a race through the mangrove swamps of BorneoldquoYoursquore not born an adventurer. I think being adventurous can be nurtured. I joined the marines at , where I then was taught in spadefuls how to be courageous and strong. But I think it was actually being in the scouts, in Kilwinning, when I was a kid that gave me that confidence to know that I could go outside on my own. I could stay outside at nightI needed to. And as a kid to have that in your back of your head, that you could probably stay out at night and not die, is quite a big thing. Confidence grows. Yoursquore just building good foundations, building mental and emotional resilience. You can learn it, whatever your age.Irsquom just about to fly out to Oman for the Expeditions series with Steve Backshall. Itrsquos part of a series of ten expeditions to do ten world firsts - whether thatrsquos been cave-ing in Mexico or kayaking and climbing in Greenland. Oman is number nine and wersquore basically climbing a big wall, about  metres high. Itrsquos a vertical clf face and itrsquos never been climbed before.Itrsquos not that hard to find firsts to do. Itrsquos actually relatively easy, even in the UK. In Scotland for example there are so many thousand kilometres of coastal sea clfs. Not every single part of it has been climbed. A couple of friends and I rowed across the Atlantic two or three years ago. We rowed from mainland Europe to mainland South America and in  that had never been done before. But Irsquom not chasing world firsts, Irsquom just chasing adventureIn the last year and a half shooting, Irsquove done some scary things. Being inside a volcano in the Congo when that erupted was pretty terrying But filming The Real Narcos [a documentary series investigating the South American drugs trade] was definitely up there as the scariest thing Irsquove done. All around the world Irsquove worked in hazardous environments, but the worst environment is people. When yoursquore dealing with a coked-up narco who is carrying a gun and hersquos just done a job thatrsquos a dferent matter. Itrsquos quite, quite frightening.Calum MacleanWild swimmer, Moment of cool: A dip in ice-covered Loch Coire an Lochain, the highest loch in Scotland.ldquoI was never a competitive swimmer as a child. I just liked being in water. About ten years ago I really got the bug for it. I put it down to one swim in particular. It was in Hobart in Australia. I was born there and half my family live there. In those days I ran a lot and cycled a lot, but I didnrsquot really swim. Therersquos a big river called the Derwent in the middle of Hobart and I was out on the bike one day and I thought, lsquoYeah, I could swim that. Letrsquos go try it.rsquo When I did it, I got a real buzz. it was a revelation. It was like, yeah, I love this. Irsquom going to keep doing stuff like this.I began blogging while I was working for the BBC and based on the Isle of Skye as a broadcast journalist. Irsquod been doing the job for about three years and I was bored of it. I started to blog and luckily at the time BBC The Social was starting for young people in Scotland and the producer asked me to do some videos. So I did a few and they were okay and then I did the water temperature chart, where instead of using temperature in degrees I talked about the water as ldquoBaltic or ldquoHoora cold or ldquoBaltic. It just took off. Irsquove even been heckled at in Tesco in Aviemore. Irsquove had strangers coming up to me, lsquoIs it Baltic Hazel RobertsonExplorer, Moment of cool: Soaking in the -hour daylight while trekking through the Arctic.ldquoProbably every time Irsquove done some new challenge, it felt like the most extreme thing Irsquod done, whether itrsquos been running across Arctic Sweden in snowshoes, or racing across the Sahara in the Marathon des Sables. Each time itrsquos felt like this is really pushing the bar a bit higher. When you do get to the end I guess itrsquos a confidence boost in yourself of having done something you werenrsquot sure you could do. Then itrsquos about looking at whatrsquos next.I guess my most extreme challenge was probably the three-month expedition that my husband Luke Robertson and I went on in , aiming to go from the southernmost to the northernmost point of mainland Alaska by sea-kayak and bike. Alaska is also this place of extremes. In the south we were starting in temperate rainforests that get  inches of rain every year, crazy wet. We were then passing all these glaciers and mountains, and then when we headed up to the Arctic and the flat, undulating tundra. Once wersquod passed the Arctic Circle we had  hour daylight for the last few weeks of our expedition. I felt so energised. It was just this absolute buzz. You almost donrsquot want to go to bed because yoursquove got so much energy.But the trip was cut short. When we hit the Arctic, we started crossing a series of lakes that are connected by rivers. Itrsquos actually the old historic trade route that the indigenous Inupiat used to kayak along. The plan was to kayak through these lakes by the rivers. And for a few lakes it was fine but as we got further inland, we realised that the water levels in these lakes were really really low and there was this sludgy mud at the bottom that the kayaks kept getting stuck in. Long story short, we found out once we got back was that actually climate change, as the air temperature is warming the permafrost that covers all of the Arctic and sits under these lakes had been starting to thaw.Robbie GrfithParkour athlete, Moment of cool: Somersaulting over a screeching car, Renton-styleldquoI think I was just ten when I started parkour. I actually went along to classes at my primary school, and there were coaches, it was like a gymnastics class just for parkour. In gymnastics itrsquos very regulated therersquos lots of rules, but in parkour there are no rules. You can move any way you want and itrsquos more creative. My most famous parkour video is a remake I made with one of my friends of the classic Choose Le scene from Trainspotting. My brother suggested we used the track for a normal parkour video. Then my dad said why donrsquot you go one better and make the actual scene, remake it in a parkour sense. We just spent a day in Edinburgh making it, edited it for a couple of days and then put it on Facebook and it blew up overnight. We woke up to having all these notications on my phone.For more details and to book tickets, visithttps:www.eventbrite e cool-conversations-tickets-

title: the-two-potential-next-presidents-of-nigeria
story: Lagos is an assault on the senses. At times the Nigerian capital is nothing short of a tumultuous pandemonium, for in the cityrsquos teeming streets are found some of the worst traffic congestion on the planet.Sitting in what can feel like an interminable log jam of vehicles, itrsquos not uncommon to see the trucks of a special paramilitary police unit with the acronym KAI emblazoned on the vehicles sides.The initials are short for the rather more colourful full name, lsquoKick Against Indiscipline Brigadersquo a law enforcement unit that is the brainchild of former Major General Muhammadu Buhari who today serves as Nigeriarsquos president.In many ways the KAI says a lot about Nigeria, set up as it was back in  to crackdown on everything from illegal petty traders to controlling the cityrsquos notorious criminal street gangs in some of the poorest neighbourhoods.Buhari the ex-general, who led a short-lived military junta back in the rsquos, was elected president in  by an electorate who by and large accepted his claim to be a ldquoreformed democrat.Four years on he rules over a country beset with problems, whose population of  million, one the largest in the world, will next weekend go to the polls in an election that will be the judge on whether Buhari is worth re-electingRunning against him is fellow septuagenarian and former vice-president Atiku Abubakar, a wealthy businessman whose pointed campaign slogan is ldquoLetrsquos Get Nigeria Working Again.Should Atiku - as hersquos widely known here - win, he will undoubtedly have his work cut out fulfilling that campaign pledge.Indeed many Nigerians argue that there is little to choose between the two leading candidates one of whom has presided over four years of lacklustre growth and the other an alleged kleptocrat of international repute.Nicknamed ldquoBaba Go-Slow by his political opponents in reference to his age and sluggish response to crises, Buhari many insist is way past his political sell by date.Atiku on the other hand continues to have trouble shaking off the air of impropriety that has surrounded his business and political dealings since .It was back then that a US Senate Report on keeping foreign corruption out of the United States concluded that Atiku and one of his wives had transferred  million of ldquosuspect funds into American accounts and said that his business dealings ldquoraise a host of questions about the nature and source of his wealth.For his part Atiku has denied the claims butone thing is certain itrsquos that corruption remains a major problem in Nigeria. Indeed many in the country and beyond regard it as a kind of plague, comprehensively infecting public officials who have embezzled vast funds generated from Nigeriarsquos crude oil exports, the mainstay of its economy.Analysts are near unanimous in their assertion that corruption is now the single greatest obstacle preventing Nigeria from achieving its enormous potential as an oil rich nation.ldquoNigerians themselves view their country as one of the worldrsquos most corrupt it perennially ranks in the bottom quartile of Transparency Internationalrsquos Corruption Perception Index, says Matthew Page, a Nigeria expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.ldquoThis is not because there is anything unique about Nigerians that make them more corrupt, Page observes, but because of a ldquoperfect storm of circumstances.Nigerias vast oil reserves he says mean, ldquotherersquos an enormous amount of money flowing into public coffers.Years of military rule prior to theto democracy in  ldquoresulted in a hollowing out of public institutions, he explains.Tales of corruption in Nigeria are legion. Page himself tells for example of the mile-long ldquomonorail to nowhere in the city of Port Harcourt.There a state governor invested  million into building it then shortly before completion, his successor halted construction. ldquoSo, its never run a single train, says Page.For analysts like Page and most ordinary Nigerians any amusement at such tales however is tempered by concern over the larger implications and impact corruption has on peoplersquos lives.Nigeria after all has now overtaken India as the worlds poverty capital, according to a report by the Brookings Institution, a US-based think-tank.The  study estimated that  million people - slightly less than half of Nigeriarsquos population, were living in extreme poverty, compared with  million in India.Four of every  people in the countryrsquos workforce are either unemployed or underemployed. Half of its population also has no electricity despite billions of dollars budgeted for power supply over the years.For many people beyond Nigeriarsquos shores this most populous country in Africa is perceived as an oil-rich state from which the majority benefit. But nothing could be further from the truth with most of the countryrsquos citizens surviving on the equivalent of  dollar or less a day.Nigeria might be oil-enriched but that is only one side of the story. This oil wealth in part accounts for its , millionaires and handful of billionaires, sixty per cent of which live in Lagos. But as with other African metropolises, Lagos has long nurtured an elite class only marginally inconvenienced by the squalor and poverty enveloping the city as a whole.In short, this is a city and country of stark contrasts and nowhere is this more apparent that in the lives of the poorest, especially young women. Of the  million adolescent girls in the world living in poverty, more than  million live in Nigeria. During my last visit to the country I was to meet some of the poorest, among them a teenage girl in Lagos called Elizabeth who lived on the streets.Elizabeth lost her mother when she was six years old and never really knew her father who was from the neighbouring West African country of Benin.Sleeping rough anywhere is a terrying experience. Here in the frenetic madness that is Nigeriarsquos capital, where somewhere between  million and  million people live, sleeping on the streets doesnrsquot bear thinking about, especially for a young woman.ldquoI used to pray before sleeping, Elizabeth told me when we met, her voice almost drowned out by the roar of a nearby ubiquitous petrol generator that provides round-the-clock power in a city where the electricity supply is erratic.Elizabethrsquos bed was wherever she could lie down in comparative safety. For over a year her nights were spent curled up on top of a sack inside a flimsy street kiosk.If darkness brought its own terrors then daytime was not much better for her.ldquoI lived by begging, sometimes I would rub menthol on my eyes to make tears, so that passersby might give me a little money, the teenager confessed.For those millions of Nigerians like Elizabeth who struggle to survive or eke out a living, next weekrsquos elections might as well be happening on the moon for all the impact it will have on their lives.But itrsquos not only corruption and widespread poverty that pose the key challenges to those politicians contesting next weekendrsquos ballot.Insecurity is also a major electoral issue for President Buhari as he seeks re-election. When he came to office in  he pledged to end attacks by the Islamist terrorist group Boko Haram but has since struggled to keep that promise.Most analysts doubt the governmentrsquos claim of victory over Boko Haram. While evidence shows that the jihadists have been pushed out of some territories they held, Boko Haram still continue to ambush security forces, launch attacks on civilians, and stage kidnappings.A recent escalation of attacks these past months has ensured that insecurity and the continuing battle against Boko Haram dominates the election campaign right now.To date the Islamist insurgency in the north east of the country has resulted in some thirty thousand deaths and the internal displacement of up to two million Nigerians. During my last visit to the volatile north eastern region I was to see for myself the horric and devastating impact this was having on peoplersquos lives there.It was during the final months of the countryrsquos dry season when I arrived in the town of Gombe. Nigerians call the town the lsquojewel in the savannahrsquo. But nothing much glitters here. Gombe might not be much of a jewel, but for one young man called Abbas his family and thousands like them, the town is a precious sanctuary of sorts.Even before speaking with Abbas I sensed from the faces of his family some of the trauma they had undergone during the five months that Boko Haram had stalked their village, Nduva, in neighbouring Borno State.ldquoWe had to stay indoors much of the time and couldnrsquot go to our farms, there was little food and water and always Boko Haram slaughtering people, Abbas told me.ldquoThey cut off peoplersquos heads with knives and placed the heads back on top of the shoulders, he continued his grisly account.ldquoThe decapitated bodies were left to rot in the street without burial, a sign that Boko Haram regard them as Kafirs ndash non-believers ndash and as a warning to others, he went on.As he told his story, nearby clearly exhausted, his elderly mother, we and children sat in the dust of the sparse rundown compound in which they now sheltered.Lined up along one wall were a handful of bulging trolley bags and holdalls containing all the personal belongings they could carry during the five gruelling days it took them to escape their village and come to this impoverished neighbourhood in Gombe.Abbas still remembered the day Boko Haram came to his village, their black flags fluttering from the speeding pick-up trucks that had heavy machine guns on tripods bolted down in the back. Some fighters also arrived on motorcycles and others on foot, quickly overrunning Nduva.ldquoThe moment you violated their instructions they either cut your throat or shot you, he recalled. ldquoI saw people tied up crouching, waiting to be butchered in this way.For what seemed like endless months, Abbas, his family, neighbours and other villagers lived in constant fear, struggling to survive as the cost of basic items soared.It was only when the Nigerian Army fought its way into the area and gaps in the Boko Haram defences opened up that Abbas family and a handful of others managed to slip away.In the days that followed, they trekked over  miles across scrubland studded with acacias and baobab trees that provided the only shelter from the searing sun. Finally they arrived at the town of Damboa, from where they journeyed to the comparative safety of Gombe.The story of Abbas and his family is far from unique and the plight of those displaced by Boko Haramrsquos violence goes on unabated. These past days as Nigeria gears up for its election, thousands of people have fled in a continuous stream over the border into neighbouring Cameroon after Boko Haram attacked the town of Rann.Andrew Mews, Country Director in Nigeria of the humanitarian organisationrsquo Medecins Sans Frontieressaid the attacks gave the lie to suggestions of improved stability in the countryrsquos north-east.ldquoThe emergency is not over yet, said Mews. ldquoTherersquos been quite a lot of talk that perhaps the situation is stabilised, and that we could start looking at doing more development activities in the north-east, but the reality is the context doesnrsquot allow that. We wish that was the case.So too no doubt does President Buhari who has staked much of his election campaigning on the claim that Boko Haram are effectively neutralised. Itrsquos against this stark unpalatable reality of the insurgents continued presence however that he will take on Atiku in the  February vote.While there are more than  other candidates, it really only boils down to these two men who between them have run for president on nine occasions. That the election matters far beyond Nigeria goes without saying.One out of every four sub-Saharan Africans is a Nigerian, and Nigeriarsquos economy is among the two largest on the continent. Given the countryrsquos heft, credible elections next week would be a boost for multi ethnic democracy in Africa. But concerns over the outcome and post election period remain.ldquoIn a society as ethnically and religiously ided as Nigeriarsquos, democracy is as fragile as an eggnot handled carefully, it could drop and shatter into a thousand pieces impossible to glue back together, warned the Polish-Nigerian journalist and political analyst Remi Adekoya last week. Few would be inclined to disagree with such an assessment.

title: scottish-parliament-msps-can-breastfeed-in-holyrood-chamber
story: Ken Macintosh was responding to a letter from the Standards Committee on whether the Parliaments standing orders are sensitive to ersity.A growing number of legislatures across the world are allowing mothers to feed their babies in debating chambers.Larissa Waters, a Green MP in Australia, addressed colleagues in  while feeding her  month old baby, Alia Joy. In Canada, Liberal MP Karina Gould breast-fed her three month old son during a debate on legalising recreational marijuana.In Scotland, following a Bill introduced by Labour MSP Elaine Smith, Holyrood passed legislation making it illegal to bar women from breastfeeding their babies in public.However, it is understood the definition of ldquopublic place in the legislation makes it unclear whether the MSPsrsquo chamber is covered by the provisions.SNP MSP Bill Kidd, who is the convener of the Standards, Procedures and Public Appointmentscommittee, wrote to Macintosh in December about a recommendations of a commission on parliamentary reform which the Presiding Officer had set up.He wrote: "The Committeehellip..agreed that it was important that there should be specic provision to ensure that Members with childcare responsibilities, particularly nursing mothers, were able to participate in Chamber business.ldquoI would therefore be gratefulyou would give consideration to Members being allowed to breastfeed in the Chamber should the need arise.A Scottish Parliament spokesperson said: ldquoThe Presiding Officer is responsible for MSPsrsquo conduct in the Chamber. He has indicated that, although the situation has yet to arise, he would always support any mother who wished to breastfeed in the Chamber.The move is expected to build on Holyroodrsquos family-friendly working hours, which were introduced when the Parliament was created in .However, although the Parliament was commended for this approach, other aspects of its operation are believed to be in need of reform.The Committee also told the Presiding Officer there should be ldquosufficient flexibility in how MSPs can use the Holyrood creche, in order to ldquofacilitate their participation in parliamentary business.By contrast, MPs are not permitted to breastfeed in the House of Commons debating chamber, a ban that angers parliamentarians.Westminsterrsquos long hours also infuriate campaigners who believe the working practices do not reflect the needs of the twenty-first century.Labour MP Tulip Siddiq, who was heavily pregnant at the time, was last month pushed through parliament in a wheelchair so she could vote on Brexit.MPs who cannot go through the Commons ision lobby because they are ill or have a small child with them can be ldquonodded through, which means their vote is still countedthey are on the parliamentary estate.Smith said: ldquoI welcome this clarication from the Presiding Officer, as it is extremely important mums are able to breastfeed whenever and wherever they want. We must turn around breastfeeding rates.

title: scotlands-50-favourite-bars-25-to-1
story: The CCA, Sauchiehall Street, GlasgowOne of the hippest joints in town after more than  years on the scene, this is still the place to hang for Glasgowrsquos arty crowd. No matter what time of day you come in ndash itrsquos open from morning till late every day of the week ndash yoursquoll find interesting people and stimulating conversation in a multitude of languages. A two-floor venue within a venue , it also serves some of the tastiest vegan food in Glasgow. And since yoursquore inside one of Europersquos most cutting edge arts centres, you might just visit an exhibition while yoursquore in.Best for: Culture vultures of all ages. A place where you can easily while away an entire day and or night.Avoid : Yoursquore into Wetherspoons.MARIANNE TAYLORBar Gandolfi Albion St, GlasgowCafeacute Gandolfi is one of the most famous restaurants in Glasgow but its little brother upstairs is less well-known. Pity that. The bar and tables are made from great oak trees and the menu is made from the best of the restaurant menu. Itrsquos a bar rather than a pub but itrsquos charming and cool and friendly. No loud music either so therersquos no need to shout.Best for: The macaroni cheese, best served with the big squishy Italian white bread.Avoid : You like live football ndash this is a big-telly-free zoneMARK SMITHMoulin Inn- Kirkmichael Road, Moulin, Pitlochry, PerthshireWith thick stone walls, a grand open fireplace and oodles of wood ling, the Moulin Inn has no shortage of cosy nooks for getting cooried-in on chilly days. The original hostelry opened its doors in  and you can feel the history in its bones. There is an adjacent brewery producing lip-smackingly good ales that are served in the pub itself.Best for: Friendly banter and hearty pub grub after a walk or cycle.Avoid : Yoursquore a fan of soulless chain pubs. They broke the mould with this one.SUSAN SWARBRICKStaggs Bar North High Street, MusselburghTucked away behind the Brunton Theatre, and well worth the detour for lovers of fine ales. Regular award-winner ndash in fact, Camra voted it the best pub in Scotland and Northern Ireland for . Small, cosy bar with an even smaller snug , it also boasts a grand selection of whiskies and rums, and an impressive wine list.Best for: Real ales and lively chat.Avoid : Youre looking for a pub meal no such fripperies here.DREW ALLANMathers Bar Queensferry Road, EdinburghSome will know that for many years there were two Mathers in the city centre: one in the west end, the other in the east. This, the west end one, has survived relatively unscathed. A relaxing daytime bolthole from the rigours of the city centre, defiantly squaring its shoulders against its trendy neighbours. A decent beer cellar, a warming fire and a TV that seems permanently tuned into the Racing Channel.Best for: An excellent steak pie washed down with a fine pint of Deuchars.Avoid : You dont do stairs .DREW ALLANThe Phoenix Nethergate, DundeeA Dundee institution, refreshingly free of the homogenised fakery of makeovers which seem to be a prerequisite of many west end pubs. Good beers and excellent bar meals combine to ensure that this is a watering hole that is regularly busy, especially at weekends ndash when its best to get there early to bag a table.Best for: Uncomplicated food and well-kept ales.Avoid : Youre not keen on straying too far from the QA waterside development.DREW ALLANClarkrsquos Bar Dundee Street, EdinburghA New Town pub to be sure but, thanks to its location way down the bottom of Dundas Street, still enough of a local to avoid being choked with tourists and Airbnb-ers. And itrsquos traditional in the best sense of the word: therersquos a bar, some bar stools, a couple of back rooms, a dartboard and the benches running theof the walls are upholstered in traditional burgundy. In short, a wood-led oasis in the heart of the capital.Best for: A quiet lunchtime pint.Avoid : You donrsquot like dogs. This is a canine-friendly howff.BARRY DIDCOCKRoseburn Bar Roseburn Terrace, EdinburghThe Roseburn, as itrsquos known, is a popular sports pub thanks to its proximity to Murrayfield and to Tynecastle, home of Hearts. But itrsquos at its best when itrsquos in quiet mode and you can really savour the atmosphere, the traditional fixtures and fittings, the memorabilia-bedecked walls and the banter of the locals. As well as the spacious public bar therersquos a lounge and a tiny third room known as the Fly Half.Best for: Earwigging and Instagramming.Avoid : Therersquos a big game on at Tynecastle. The pub is colonised by away fans before and Hearts fans after, and theres always a fat man in a red, green or blue morph suit doing something silly with a traffic cone.BARRY DIDCOCKLeith Depot Leith Walk, EdinburghA bar and music venue that up until a few weeks ago was near the top of the list of endangered pubs. Leith Depot has been at the heart of the Save Leith Walk campaign, which has been fighting to stop a plan by developer Drum Property to knock down the buildings on its stretch and build a boutique hotel and student accommodation. But Leithers donrsquot like it when you go for their pubs or local businesses. After plenty of objections, councillors rejected the proposal. The Leith Depot lives on ndash though for how long  ndash bringing great food and music to a spot that was formerly one of the worst pubs on the Walk.Best for: Live musicAvoid : You donrsquot want to get into a conversation about local planning.VICKY ALLANThe Variety Bar Sauchiehall St, GlasgowSauchiehall Street may not be the first place you associate with fine pubs. Most open and close in the time it takes to down a pint. Not The Variety. Its been here since .Its been through a few rocky years but its had a recent makeover which has retained the bars edgy alternative feel and brought in a few more customers.Ive been coming here with the same friend for nearly  years and whenever I suggest somewhere , he gently steers me here. To have a pub survive this long, and a friendship too, has got to mean something in this ever-changing world.Best for: Art deco interior.Avoid : You are after the latest trend.GARRY SCOTTMash Tun Bier House  Kitchen Easter Road, EdinburghHandily situated a hefty clearance from Hibernian FCs stadium, this is a popular watering hole for football fans ndash home and away ndash on matchdays. Packed to the rafters for two hours either side of the game, it has a good selection of cask ales, lagers and a long list of bottled beers. Dog-friendly, though probably not recommended for the pooch at half-past two when Hibs are at home. Offers a good selection of pub food.Best for: Those seeking to explore hitherto-unknown beers.Avoid : You suffer from agoraphobia .DREW ALLANGFT Rose St, GlasgowAfter extensive renovations to the art deco building, the Glasgow Film Theatrersquos bars are looking smarter than ever. There are two to choose from, with the one upstairs, next to Cinema , the larger. Gets very busy just before screenings and this monthrsquos Glasgow Film Festival, running from February -March , means it will be standing room only for a week and a half.Best for: Taking your drinks into the cinema.Avoid : You donrsquot like listening to film critics, who use the place as an office during the festival, bore on.ALISON ROWATThe  Kelvinhaugh St, GlasgowWonderful beerand even more wonderful vegan food . The menu is small but thats because its made properly, not heated up with a ping.Best for: the vegan food .Avoid : yoursquore in a rush ndash the service can sometimes be a wee bit slow. But chill! Enjoy yourself.MARK SMITHPrince of Wales St Nicholas St, AberdeenAn earthy, unpretentious favourite of anyone whorsquos in the mood for a pint without the faff. People have been having pints in here since the th century and in all the best respects itrsquos the same as it ever was. Find a corner in the labyrinthine layout and stay there all night and day. That man in the beard at the bar knows his beer and hersquos always here so youre on to a good thing.Best for: the famously long bar which gives you a good view of all the best Scottish ales it has to offer.Avoid : you judge a pub by its decor. The Prince was done up a few years ago, but the shabbiness is one of the reasons its fans love it.MARK SMITHKayrsquos Bar Jamaica Street, EdinburghHidden away in an unprepossessing side-street in the New Town, Kayrsquos enjoyed best-kept-secret status for many years. But in these Trip Advisor and Instagram-obsessed days its photogenic appeal and prodigious choice of whiskies have made it a popular attraction for visitors and in particular the Six Nations crowd, who ensure you can barely move inside on match days. Accepting the truth of the old maxim ldquo you canrsquot beat them, join them, Kayrsquos now has its own website. Itrsquos still well worth a visit, though.Best for: Rare single malts.Avoid : Therersquos a rugby international on.BARRY DIDCOCKThe BungoNithsdale Road, GlasgowThis lovely south side bar and restaurant was one of the first to capitalise on Strathbungorsquos now well-established reputation as one of Glasgowrsquos ndash indeed Scotlandrsquos ndash coolest neighbourhoods. Friendly and relaxedit has a loyal following among the brunch craft beer crowd thanks to an eye-catching menu and some excellent pop-up foodie nights.Best for: Weekend bloody Marys and weeknight pints. Avoid : Yoursquore after Scotch pie and beans.MARIANNE TAYLORThe Abbotsford- Rose Street, EdinburghAcross the road from the rear entrance of Jenners, this fine specimen of Edwardian splendour still has a magnicent mahagony island bar , and a rather good restaurant upstairs . Bench seating which can be a bit awkward when rammed with truanting shoppers, as it often is.Best for: Startinga Rose Street expedition.Avoid : Youre not keen on squeezing up next to strangers on the bench seating.DREW ALLANThe Sparkle Horse,  Dowanhill Street, GlasgowFormerly the Dowanhill pub, the Sparkle Horse has maintained all the charm of a typical local boozer without the sticky carpets or wafting fag smoke. Just off Dumbarton road, the dog-friendly venue is ideal for a quiet mid-week pint or a brain-stretching pub quiz on a Monday. Friday and Saturday nights, yoursquoll find it tight to get a table after around pm but hang around long enough and yoursquoll be sure to make new pals you can squeeze in beside. The limited but excellent menu offers main courses from pound, and with vegan and veggie options it usually has something to suit everyonersquos tastes.Best for: Good tunes, cheap eats and friendly service.Avoid: If you donrsquot like dogs or are looking for somewhere to lsquopre-drinkrsquo.HANNAH RODGERThe Clachaig Inn, BallachulishWhat better way to relax after a day tramping in the hills than with a pint and a spot of live music  The Clachaig Inn, which has been welcoming weary travellers with its hospitality for the past  years, has certainly got the beers and musicians well and truly covered. Thanks to its location in the heart of Glencoe it has breathtaking views to boot, making it just as ideal for al fresco summer lunches as it is for cosy autumn evenings.Best for: Post mountain relaxation dancing.Avoid : Dirty boots arenrsquot your thing.MARGARET TAYLORThe Sheeprsquos Heid- The Causeway, EdinburghBest arrived at after a bracing hike over Arthurrsquos Seat, the historic Sheep Heid feels like a country pub in a quaint village complete with loch. Yet it itrsquos a skip and a hop ndash over the hill ndash from Edinburghrsquos city centre to its location in Duddingston. First established in , the inn boasts that it has been ldquofeeding and watering people for more than six centuries. Therersquos a glorious beer garden for the sunny months. But the best thing is about it is the skittles. Out the back, the oldest bowling alley in Scotland is for hire.Best for: Retro bowlingAvoid : Yoursquore bringing the dog ndash itrsquos surprisingly not dog-friendly.VICKY ALLANFour Marys  High Street, Linlithgow, West LothianJust a stones throw from Linlithgow Palace, the pub gets its name from the four ladies in waiting who attended Mary, Queen of Scots. The anaesthetic properties of chloroform were reportedly discovered in a room above this watering hole in . Theres even said to be a resident ghost called Agnes, a reputed witch who was burned at the stake.Best for: Soaking up a magical history tour.Avoid : Ye olde coaching inn charm isnrsquot your vibeSUSAN SWARBRICKThe Tron Bar Trongate, GlasgowBEFORE the refit, the Tron Bar was an art house meeting place, the perfect Friday night venue in which to end the week.It was music-free and bustley, it was redolent of a Soho bar restaurant, it feared an eclectic range of ageing hippies and New Romantics, it was a place to be for those who ignored time, and sometimes social convention.The new bar area is greatitrsquos still fun and full of new people and the vaguely familiar. It still features the debate on the play performed next door, but just lacks the odd delightfully drunken pretentious conversation of old, or political analysis.Best For: Food and friendliness.Avoid: If you want a long night out.BRIAN BEACOMThe Red Deer, Auchenkilns, CumbernauldYoull have been in this place ... though maybe not in Cumbernauld.
